Mechanical duality
Up to the writing of this report we have received two
complaints on the mechanical <cuality of tapes circulated* These
two both were about the series, Los Angeles County Museum Chamber
Music Concerts* This brings up a very important problem0
First, let us consider the specific program about which
complaints were received* This series has not operated on an
ideal basis* Not all of the tapes, nor all the information on
the series was at hand when the series started. Some of the tapes
on which it was received were in very poor physical condition* It
was the first series which vie sent out* It was done rather hurriedly*
It is possible th?t either in the original recording, or in dubbing
them sticky tape caused occasional distortions. It may have been the
result of poor dubbing here* 'When the tapes mentioned as poor are
returned, we will check every possible cause.
As to mechanical quality in general, be have not thus far
had equipment of sufficient character to accurately check on quality,
We hope this will be remedied very soon. It also seems necessary to
set quite definite standards for the recording of programs, especially
music. Tapes in the best possible mechanical condition should be
used for the .lasters. It is assumed that the mass duplicator will
result in a high degree of fidelity. The problem seems to be,
therefore, to get good masters*
When the quality of music programs is to be judged, what
is needed is a person with sufficient musical acumen to note subtle
distortions* Such a person is available at the University, If
his services can be obtained for this purf^^n^Qlhelp to
avoid any future difficulties with the mechanical quality of
musical programs*
